comments.commentBody:
As president, I believe that Romney would not be much different from President Obama, whom I fully support, if we rely on his Massachusetts' governorship as evidence. Both are dispassionate, pragmatic men who do not let party ideologies determine their policies and, therefore, do bend in negotiations (although I doubt Romney would bend on the issue of raising capital gains rates and ending the carried interest tax perk.) As you do, my big worry is the nuts in Congress who with a Republican in the White House will most certainly write up a lot of very destructive legislation. The "perfectly lubricated weather vane" would sign the nonsense into law if that gave him support for the next election.

As Romney is campaigning, of course, we now only see the pragmatic, dishonest man, who will say what needs to be said, even if it is a lie, to get elected. A President Romney, if there were a Democratic Congress, would be tolerable. Without that check, he would be a disaster.
If District residents want to live in a state they can move to the moon.  Same with the Puerto Ricans.  Same with illegal immigrants.  One solution to many problems.
Moonside Republican, Earthside Democrat. I think we just solved the American polarization problem.

I find it interesting that Newt Gingrich raised the possibility of statehood for his fantasy moon colony when back in the 1990s he was vehemently opposed to statehood for the residents of Washington DC. I guess he figures that his moon colony would be filled with Republicans (we can only hope!).

As for Romney, a loss in Florida is not needed to show that his candidacy is in question. Romney has always been the natural frontrunner in the race yet GOP voters have been extremely reluctant to coalesce around him. So reluctant, in fact, that they have flirted with Gingrich, Santorum, Perry, Bachmann, and Cain, each of whom should never be anywhere near the White House.

The problem for Romney is two fold. First, is his Mormonism, which consists of a different set of myths than those believed by the evangelicals that make up a large percentage of the GOP base. The gap between those two religious sects is so large that many evangelicals simply won't vote for Romney.

The second is that Romney's complete lack of any core convictions or beliefs worries many conservatives that Romney won't be with them on the key issues. I am far more concerned that his lack of convictions means that a President Romney wouldn't stand up to the crazies who have taken over the GOP. But if conservatives decide not to turn out for Romney in the general election, more power to them.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

You asked "Why isn't the UN, the entire Arab world, all those liberal blowhards who condemn Israel every moment of their lives, standing up and stating enough is enough - this tinpot dictator who inherited his power from his ruthless father has got to be eliminated?"

From the FIRST paragraph of the article:

"Violence in Syria has escalated sharply in the past two days, with heavy bloodshed reported Friday in at least three flash points as Arab League monitors expressed exasperation and the United Nations Security Council prepared to discuss the crisis as a step toward a possible resolution condemning President Bashar al-Assad’s government."

Also from the article:

"At the Security Council on Friday, diplomats from Western and Arab nations were holding talks on a draft resolution that would condemn Mr. Assad’s government, and there were expectations that a vote could be held next week. "

If you google it, the King of Jordan has also called Assad to step down.

Next time you have an axe to grind about Israel, maybe you should actually read the article first.

It seems that this is something of a class war, the privileged under the Assad regime against the others, revolting now for some political power. And, the privileged have become a sizable part of Syrian society; so they have staying power. Were it not for the inspiration of 'The Arab Spring' uprisings, this Syrian revolt probably would have been put down long ago.

Now, as elsewhere, the people are not afraid to die, and Assad is by no means isolated. He has the Syrian military firmly behind him and most of Damascus society. This could be a long-running tragedy, ending who knows how.
Tactical nukes?  Are you crazy?  Strategic attacks like against Bin Laden or the kidnap rescue in Somalia is a better alternative.
I also wonder how many of them are foreign fighters who want to de-stablize Syria and not the Syrian people who want a free Syria, but I'm sure its both.  Think al Qaeda or the Taliban.

Syria is a terrorist nation shielding Hamas, supporting Hezbollah, siding with Iran, ruining democracy in Lebanon. The piper is being paid. Justice is being done. Also Russia is being exposed as evil and the UN as impotent and hypocritical. And the the antisemites scurrying for cover.

If the President Mubarack imprisoment and Kadaffy's death are an example, Mr Assad would be lucky if he gets to trial alive. The brutality of his repsonse is only a reflection of his numbing fear. .....at this point a civil war is unavoidable.

>> signaling an escalation of violence in this beleaguered country.

This is obviously the beginning of the end for Assad's murder-regime, yet the reporting here, or maybe it's the editing, seems incredibly obtuse. Would you have written about Valley Forge as an "escalation of violence" against the British Crown, or the Normandy Invasion as "destabilizing" for Hitler's regime? Good grief.

The Arab League's involvement is apt to be fair-weather at best. After all, nations such as Saudi Arabia & Kuwait (among others) are basically well-to-do dictatorships, albeit pro-Western & US-friendly. So it's not really in their best interests to punish Syria, topple the government, or give the Arab Spring movement any more credibility, lest their own citizentry get the same ideas.

It's understandable that Russia is worried about instability affecting its sea access. One worry is likely the increasingly-bold nation of Turkey; even though relations have improved greatly between Turkey & Russia (both of which have historically been bitter enemies), Russia is probably leery of Turkey. In recent months, Turkey has distanced itself from cozy ties with Syria & is looking at a refugee exodus of fleeing Syrians (plus displaced Iraqis that fled to Syria), & Turkey has not been shy about pursuing Kurdish separatists across the Iraqi border recently. If Syria topples, Turkey might be in the right place at the right time with its strong miltary. (Add to that the prospect of an Iraqi civil war, & the stakes get higher for strengthening Turkey's role in the region.)

Another country to watch: Iran. Syria & Iran have been longtime allies, & Iran has been curiously hands-off.
If Syria falls, can there be any doubt Iraq would have done the same without us?

amazing how many people feel the need to use this as some sort of moral relativism with israeli criticism.

it is apples and oranges. but shows the organized pr power of the zionists, i imagine most of these posts are from a PR firm in Tel aviv...or boston.

I heard an amusing, but perhaps not true, anecdote that when, in a moment of humility, Gingrich sought Dole's advice about why people took an instant dislike to him.  Dole replied "Because it saves time."

Dear Comrade Martin,

Perhaps you should take the possibility of a Lunar Colony in the future seriously because the Chinese Government does, as do the Russians. They, the Russians are holding discussions on the subject with NASA as we speak. That would be NASA under President Obama so how much fantasy could their be? I imagine that since you can't speak to the Acomplishments of your candidate you must attack the other possible choices.

If you require something to discuss what about the $350 donated to charity by V.P. Joe Biden in contrast to the $3.5 million donated by Govenor Romney or the 3 years it took for the current Administration to begin to investigate the Home Loan Scandal as opposed to the hundreds of trials and convictions by a Republican Administration during the S and L Scandal in the same 3 year span?
Am I alone in thinking that Newt should be hospitalized now?

I would trust anything Dole said, as a man who was a former distinguished United States senator a badly wounded WW ll war hero who literally came back from the dead, and former candidate for POTUS, who was not above being the spokesperson for Viagra and making a commercial with Britteny Spears in which he portrayed himself as a lecherous dirty old man.

I mean that. Though not generally fond of the GOP. I always found Dole to have a sharp biting if not a bit self deprecating wit, characteristic of people ample intelligence. Given the dour, humorless, hypocritical, sexually repressed and extremist lot of GOP aspirants, the establishment GOP would do well to heed his advice. If John McCain had Dole's sense of humor he might have defeated Obama. I also can't envision someone as politically astute as Dole accepting a Sarah Palin as a running mate, his commercial with Britney Spears not withstanding.

Newts colony on the moon rant was the first indication of his mania spinning a bit out of control, unless Ron Paul talked him into trying to see what it would be like if marijuana was legal and slipped Newt a couple of brownies to sample.

If New became president I think he would be the first president to be institutionalized as mentally unfit to continue in office. This may sound somewhat hyperbolic, but not that much. I think the power of the presidency would be too much for Newt's megalomania and he'd mentally overdose and try to establish a Newtocracy rather than simply govern

That's a supply side myth. Corporations are sitting on over $1 trillion cash, interest rates are at historic lows, and the Federal Reserve has flooded the market with dollars, which is spilling out into commodity speculation. There is no shortage of funds for 'private sector GDP', the problem is on the demand side, not the supply side. And the only way to increase demand is higher paying jobs, and higher wages for existing jobs. Doubling teachers' salaries would certainly contribute to that.
Clever. Well done.
HILARIOUS!
I fully support Newt's conviction that only heterosexuals should have the right to cheat on their spouses.  And that only draft-dodgers should have the authority to send the nation to war.
Jane and James: The Arabian Peninsula, the southeastern corner of which is occupied by Oman, is shaped like a boot.
Thanks, Blanche.. I always think of Italy as the boot.

Jane,

There's usually a box 'keep me logged in'; you probably have that checked. It also says 'not recommended for shared computers'

Oh, Deb, I couldn't figure out 33A - ENS...I LOL when I read what it meant in your column and I still don't get OMAN... all in all - not a difficult puzzle - didn't need to Google but I did go thru the alphabet many times to begin or end words. so I was soooo slow...

49A really confused me... At first I thought Barry S was talking about snail mail; then when I figured out LOG ON, I was still confused. I don't have to log on to my email program, only to web sites that I don't go to very often. Maybe I'm being to literal. Oh, I tried ello before GDAY - wrong continent...

Oh, maybe I should google ALPHA RAY... another unknown for me. not tonight...too late...

"We came from a time when many rapes or sexual assaults were unreported, with victims, mostly females, denied their rights"

Are you under the impression that this is no longer happening?

When I graduated Yale in the 60s the University did not even compute or report a GPA. However, I would say that very few students would have gotten such a GPA had it been computed. Most professors or instructors would tell us at the start of a course that if we did everything related to the course that was required, and it was average quality for the class, that translated to a C.

I would like to submit that a vital matter is being overlooked in all the hoopla over whose side of the story is accurate as to whether the application was withdrawn or invalidated.  Even if Patrick Witt's version of events is true, it is clear that he values football over scholarship, his reputed GPA notwithstanding.  Anyone who prioritizes football over a Rhodes Scholarship should not be given a Rhodes Scholarship.  Let this gift of a lifetime go to a scholar who cares more about the acquisition of knowledge.
Josie, you are calling him an idiot, when in the same breath you are saying that history and humanities (all of it?) are nothing important.

Are we to believe that the Times truly does not know the victim's name, even after talking to a half-dozen sources, learning, among other things, how, when and to whom the sexual assault complaint was made?  It's great that all the anonymous sources can keep a secret, but what editor runs a story with such a crucial unknown?
the Enquirer would have been more honest

When you say a "pattern of a lack of integrety on the part of all concerned" you implicitly impugn the integrity of the accuser as well. She is one of the "all concerned" here. But because there is zero examination of the accuser, we have no way of judging her integrity or lack thereof at all.

Not enough is actually known or reported to know whether there was an attempt to game the standards or not.

There is no legal jurisdictional exclusion that excludes college campuses from the application of federal and state criminal statutes.  From the very beginning, the accuser had and still has access to the protection of these statutes.  SHE chose not to avail herself of their protections; NOT the University.   The statute of limitations that would prevent her claim from an airing in the real legal system has not yet run.  I fully agree with you that this should be dealt with in a court of law and not via a dubious shadow system that is supposedly confidential but allows for anonymous leaks that are published by once-respectable newspapers.

I agree that Yale's "in-house" informal reporting system obviously invites abuse.  But that said, simply put, no college or university in America is treated as an autonomous state a la Vatican City.   They are subject to the same jurisdictional application of state and federal criminal statutes as any geographic area that is not a college campus but otherwise located within the USA.  The accuser may avail herself of the protection of the law and may still report the alleged sexual assault to the police.  SHE chose not to; not the state of Connecticut nor the university.

I'm glad you are going to complain. This paragraph disgusted and infuriated me:
Connecticut law does not require colleges to report suspected sex offenses, and experts say the vast majority of campus sexual assaults are not reported, either to college authorities or to the police.
